channel.title: Ggplot on Academic
channel.description: Recent content in Ggplot on Academic

item.title: blog 2017-09-28 line plot 9-27
item.description:
A Line graph is great way to show data over time.

Ok we need to go through all the circus of installing packages and bringing them into R studio with library:

library(devtools)
library(Lahman)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggiraph)

We’ll extract some dat afor our time series:

df<-Batting%>%
  filter(playerID=='ruthba01')%>%
  select(yearID,HR)

and add a simple line graph

ggplot()+
  geom_line(data=df, aes(x=yearID, y=HR))

Not too exciting: no title, it would be nice to have some points to know numbers. So let’s to our plotting code:

ggplot()+
  geom_line(data=df, aes(x=yearID, y=HR))+
  geom_point(data=df,aes(x=yearID,y=HR))+
  ggtitle("Babe Ruth HomeRuns")

Now that is definately improved. But wait… there’s more. Act now and we can make this an interactive graph with hover points.

-as a special bonus you get the following included at no additional charge.

The funFact for Today, 9-27-2017 is that Google is 19 years old today. Happy Birthday Google. But even of more note is that yesterday was my 19th wedding anniversary. So my marraige is one day older than Google.

g<-ggplot()+
  geom_line(data=df, aes(x=yearID, y=HR))+
  geom_point_interactive(data=df,aes(x=yearID,y=HR,tooltip=HR,data_id=yearID))+
  ggtitle("Babe Ruth HomeRuns")
                       
ggiraph(code=print(g),hover_css = "fill:white;stroke:blue")

It’s outta here…

item.title: Blog 2017-09-27 Data Visualization Bar Graph round 2
item.description:
Let’s revisit our prior 9-25 post on bar graphs. We will talk a little bit about varaible types. First we need to install packages 7 load libraries (just like our previous posts):

library(devtools)
library(Lahman)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggiraph)

So when we look at our prior code, we defines a variable called ‘df$name.’ What we want to find out is what type variable it is.

df<-Teams%>%
  filter(yearID==1980)%>%
  select(name,HR)%>%
  arrange(HR)
df$name<-factor(df$name,levels=df$name)

next

item.title: Blog 2017-09-26 Data Visualization Histogram Plot (9-25)
item.description:
OK so the most important thing is to make sure that you ‘save’ the file from class with the working Histogram code. ’Cause if you don’t have that working code, it’s kind of hard to blog about it. Many thanks to Judy for providing the critical piece of informtion that I did not have.

A histogram is a good graph when you have one column of numerical data.

(Again) as with any r-studio project we will need to install packages & then load libraries. In R-studio go to tools (at the top menu bar) click on “install packages”. Type devtool in the pop up box and click on install button. Repeat installation for Lahman, dplyr, ggplot, and ggiraph. To install blogdown. Then bring in the libraries for devtools, Lahman, dplyr, ggplot, and ggiraph.

library(devtools)
library(Lahman)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggiraph)

Now we need some data. Weight: Players weights ovr time would be some interesting data.

df<-Master%>%
  select(weight)

ggplot()+
  geom_histogram(data=df,aes(x=weight))
## `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.
## Warning: Removed 854 rows containing non-finite values (stat_bin).

Ok so the graph looks good, but we’ve got a couple of error messages.

‘Removed 854 rows containing non-finite values (stat_bin)’ That means we’ve got some player data without weight information.

We need to filter out all the blank weights. We use the ! for not:

We’re also getting a bin error: “stat_bin() using bins = 30. Pick better value with binwidth”. That means that we need to have more ‘bars’ or bins to put the data in. (and let’s add a title too)

df<-Master%>%
  filter(!is.na(weight))%>%
  select(weight)
ggplot()+
  geom_histogram(data=df,aes(x=weight),bins=25)+
  ggtitle("Baseball Player Weights")

Ok now that looks pretty good & no errors.

How about a little color:

df<-Master%>%
  filter(!is.na(weight))%>%
  select(weight)

ggplot()+
  geom_histogram(data=df,aes(x=weight),color="White",fill="green",bins=25)+
  ggtitle("Baseball Player Weights")

So that does it for Histograms.
And this is a record blog: only 2 hours.

item.title: Blog 2017-09-25 Data Visualization Bar Graph
item.description:
What else I learned note: Important, when creating a blog, don’t try to copy in info from a word document (the Rmarkdown file doesn’t like it). You’ll only have to scrap what you’ve done & start over.

So now let’s explore a bar chart.

As with any r-studio project we will need to install packages & then load libraries. In R-studio go to tools (at the top menu bar) click on “install packages”. Type devtool in the pop up box and click on install button. Repeat installation for Lahman, dplyr, ggplot, and ggiraph. To install blogdown. Then bring in the libraries for devtools, Lahman, dplyr, ggplot, and ggiraph.

library(devtools)
library(Lahman)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggiraph)

Now we need some data. How about the total team Home Runs from 1980. The summer of 1980 I had just finished my Freshman year of High School; I was officially a Sophmore (ie wise fool).

df<-Teams%>%
  filter(yearID==1980)%>%
  select(name,HR)

As in our scatter plot (previous post) we’ve defined our data with “df<-”. The “%>%”" is a continuation character.

The basic graph is next. With the bar chart we need to add “stat=‘identity’”:

ggplot()+
  geom_bar(data=df,aes(x=name,y=HR),stat="identity")

Whoa

Well, we have a graph, but we can’t read the team names on the bottom. We need to flip the axis.

ggplot()+
  geom_bar(data=df,aes(x=name,y=HR),stat="identity")+
  coord_flip()

Much Better Now, I really can’t tell (easily) if the Astros had more Home Runs than the Padres. What we need to do is to put these in order.

Simply, adding “arrange” to the dplyr code for our base data didn’t work. So what we need to do is add in a factor.

df<-Teams%>%
  filter(yearID==1980)%>%
  select(name,HR)%>%
  arrange(HR)
df$name<-factor(df$name,levels=df$name)
ggplot()+
  geom_bar(data=df,aes(x=name,y=HR),stat="identity")+
  coord_flip()

Now we’re cooking with gas

Ok let’s add some color and we’re done:

df<-Teams%>%
  filter(yearID==1980)%>%
  select(name,HR)%>%
  arrange(HR)
df$name<-factor(df$name,levels=df$name)
ggplot()+
  geom_bar(data=df,aes(x=name,y=HR),stat="identity",color="blue",fill="white")+
  coord_flip()

end

item.title: Blog 2017-09-24 Data Visualization (blog#2)
item.description:
OK so this is attempt 3 for this blog post. We’re (that would be the royal we-I don’t have a mouse in my pocket) going to get the text up & then work from there.

We used R-studio to create a scatter plot of baseball information (from the Lahman library). Aside from learning how to do the scatter plot, the most interesting thing I learned is that the “css” that I keep seeing in the sample blog has to do with viewing the HTML information. I had been wondering what all of them were (and now I know)

I. Our first step was to open r-studio and install all the packages we would need and then bring them all in with ‘library’:

  • Lahman
  • dplyr
  • ggplot2
  • ggiraph: which is the HTML widget (no clue what that means-but let’s move on)
  • so I figued out how to make the bullet points above by adding a space after the dash

II. We pulled some interesting information: players with more than 400 career Home runs, but we also wanted to know the number of strikeouts too. We used the following code:

Batting %>% group_by(playerID)%>% summarize(career_HR=sum(HR), career_SO=sum(SO))%>% filter(career_HR >=400)

Since we will be using this information to create graph, we want to define it as a table. The table name is df. we put a ‘df<-’ (the carrot & dash make a little arrow) before ‘batting’ and then after the code close/end the table with another ‘df’ a space below.

III. We then created our graph using ggplot, in the same way that the ‘%>%’ is the continuation character for r markdown, the ‘+’ is the continuation character for ggplot. the ‘aes’ (asthetic) is for the xy axis. The geom_point indicates we want a scatter plot (points). If we wanted some other type, like a bar chart we would use geom_bar. ggtitle gives our graph it’s name, and the xlab & ylab (label) give the axes names.

ggplot()+ geom_point_interactive(data=HR_vs_SO,aes(x=career_SO,y=career_HR))+ ggtitle(“career Homeruns vs. Strikeouts for great hitters”)+ xlab(“Career Strikeouts”)+ ylab(“Career Homeruns”)

again we want to ‘save’ this so we name it (like we did the batting information) ‘g<-’ before ggplot.

This gives us a nice visual, but we don’t know what (or rather who) the points represent.

IV. So we use colnames(master) to find out the table names in the Lahman information. Now we want to ‘paste’ together the first & last names. The following code is added to the ‘Batting’ code to show the first & last names:

HR_vs_SO<-inner_join(df,Master,by=c(‘playerID’))%>% select(nameFirst,nameLast,career_HR,career_SO)

HR_vs_SO$name<-paste(HR_vs_so$nameFirst, HR_vs_so$nameLast)

‘V.’ Now we add a little more code we define the name as a tool tip & modify our gg plot code so that as we hover over our points, we get the names:

geom_point_interactive(data=HR_vs_SO,aes(x=career_SO,y=career_HR,tooltip=name, data_id=nameLast))

VI.Ok, so the final code looks like this:

df<-Batting %>% group_by(playerID)%>% summarize(career_HR=sum(HR), career_SO=sum(SO))%>% filter(career_HR >=400)

df

HR_vs_SO<-inner_join(df,Master,by=c(‘playerID’))%>% select(nameFirst,nameLast,career_HR,career_SO)

HR_vs_SO$name<-paste(HR_vs_so$nameFirst, HR_vs_so$nameLast)

HR_vs_SO #————————————————-

g<-ggplot()+ geom_point_interactive(data=HR_vs_SO,aes(x=career_SO,y=career_HR,tooltip=name, data_id=nameLast))+ ggtitle(“career Homeruns vs. Strikeouts for great hitters”)+ xlab(“Career Strikeouts”)+ ylab(“Career Homeruns”)+

HR_vs_SO$name<-paste(HR_vs_so$nameFirst,HR_vs_so$nameLast)

ggiraph(code=print(g),hover_css = “fill:white;stroke:black”)

Note: I’m using Roman numerals because when I tried ‘1,2’3” it made them all “1”. I found some info on line about “ordered lists” in HTML, but I’m not sure how to insert it into the HTML file (I think it will go in the public/post/index.html file. I’m going to need to find out a little bit more to be sure.

item.title: Blog 2017-09-24 Data Visualization (blog#2.4)
item.description:
OK so this is attempt 4 for this blog post. So my AHa shower moment was “I’m using the wrong file format.” Sure enough, I was using an “.md” file, but I needed a “.Rmd” file. Ok so then I was still having issues (well, I have issues so let’s clarify-issues with the site giving me an error when I tried to build it). So copy someone elses work & make changes so that it fits your original intent (& it isn’t plagiarism -btw-thank’s Jorge). So now we’re cooking with gas. I can get rid of the info I don’t understand & add things like summary & the site will build. Yes & I figured out (on my own) how to get that “build” bold).

The text is the same, but this time I have the code inserted that I want.

We used R-studio to create a scatter plot of baseball information (from the Lahman library). Aside from learning how to do the scatter plot, the most interesting thing I learned is that the “css” that I keep seeing in the sample blog has to do with viewing the HTML information. I had been wondering what all of them were (and now I know)

I. Our first step was to open r-studio and install all the packages we would need and then bring them all in with ‘library’:

library(devtools)
library(Lahman)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggiraph)
  1. We pulled some interesting information: players with more than 400 career Home runs, but we also wanted to know the number of strikeouts too. We used the following code:
df<-Batting %>%
  group_by(playerID)%>%
  summarize(career_HR=sum(HR), career_SO=sum(SO))%>%
  filter(career_HR >=400)
  1. We then created our graph using ggplot, in the same way that the ‘%>%’ is the continuation character for r markdown, the ‘+’ is the continuation character for ggplot. the ‘aes’ (asthetic) is for the xy axis. The geom_point indicates we want a scatter plot (points). If we wanted some other type, like a bar chart we would use geom_bar. ggtitle gives our graph it’s name, and the xlab & ylab (label) give the axes names.
HR_vs_SO<-inner_join(df,Master,by=c("playerID"))%>%
  select(nameFirst,nameLast,career_HR,career_SO)

g<-ggplot()+
  geom_point_interactive(data=HR_vs_SO,aes(x=career_SO,y=career_HR))+
  ggtitle("Career Home Runs vs Strike Outs for Great Hitlers.")+
  xlab("Career Strikeouts")+
  ylab("Career Homeruns")

Again we want to ‘save’ this so we name it (like we did the batting information) ‘g<-’ before ggplot.

This gives us a nice visual, but we don’t know what (or rather who) the points represent.

  1. So we use colnames(master) to find out the table names in the Lahman information. Now we want to ‘paste’ together the first & last names. The following code is added to the ‘Batting’ code to show the first & last names:
HR_vs_SO<-inner_join(df,Master,by=c('playerID'))%>%
  select(nameFirst,nameLast,career_HR,career_SO)

‘V.’ Now we add a little more code we define the name as a tool tip & modify our gg plot code so that as we hover over our points, we get the names:

geom_point_interactive(data=HR_vs_SO,aes(x=career_SO,y=career_HR,tooltip=name, data_id=nameLast))

and add some color to our visual:

ggiraph(code=print(g),hover_css=“Fill:white;stroke:blue”)

VI.Ok, so the final code looks like this:

df<-Batting%>%
  group_by(playerID)%>%
  summarize(career_HR=sum(HR),career_SO=sum(SO))%>%
  filter(career_HR >= 400)

HR_vs_SO<-inner_join(df,Master,by=c("playerID"))%>%
  select(nameFirst,nameLast,career_HR,career_SO)

HR_vs_SO$name<-paste(HR_vs_SO$nameFirst,HR_vs_SO$nameLast)

g<-ggplot()+
  geom_point_interactive(data=HR_vs_SO,aes(x=career_SO,y=career_HR,tooltip=nameLast,data_id=nameLast))+
  ggtitle("Career Home Runs vs Strike Outs for Great Hitlers.")+
  xlab("Career Strikeouts")+
  ylab("Career Homeruns")

ggiraph(code=print(g),hover_css="Fill:white;stroke:blue")
